defs.docs: A procedural noise generation library for Rust.

attributes.value: / A procedural noise generation library for Rust.
/ # Example
/ ```rust
/ use noise::{NoiseFn, Perlin};
/ let perlin = Perlin::new();
/ let val = perlin.get([42.4, 37.7, 2.8]);
deny(missing_copy_implementations)

defs.name: Cache
defs.docs:
Noise function that caches the last output value generated by the source
 function.

attributes.value: / Noise function that caches the last output value generated by the source
/ function.
/ If the input coordinates passed to `Cache::get` are equal to the previous
/ call, the function returns the cached result of the previous call to
/ `Source::get`. Otherwise, `Source::get` is called with the new coordinates,
/ overwriting the cache with the result, and returning the result to the
/ caller.
/ Caching a noise function is useful if it is used as a source function for
/ multiple noise functions. If a source function is not cached, the source
/ function will redundantly calculate the same output value once for each
/ noise function in which it is included.

defs.name: source
defs.docs: Outputs the value to be cached.

attributes.value: / Outputs the value to be cached.

defs.name: Checkerboard
defs.docs: Noise function that outputs a checkerboard pattern.

attributes.value: / Noise function that outputs a checkerboard pattern.
/ This noise function can take one input, size, and outputs 2<sup>size</sup>-sized
/ blocks of alternating values. The values of these blocks alternate between
/ This noise function is not very useful by itself, but it can be used for
/ debugging purposes.

defs.name: Constant
defs.docs: Noise function that outputs a constant value.

attributes.value: / Noise function that outputs a constant value.
/ This function takes a input, value, and returns that input for all points,
/ producing a constant-valued field.
/ This function is not very useful by itself, but can be used as a source
/ function for other noise functions.

defs.docs: Constant value.

attributes.value: / Constant value.

defs.name: Cylinders
defs.docs: Noise function that outputs concentric cylinders.

attributes.value: / Noise function that outputs concentric cylinders.
/ This noise function outputs concentric cylinders centered on the origin. The
/ cylinders are oriented along the z axis similar to the concentric rings of
/ a tree. Each cylinder extends infinitely along the z axis.

defs.name: frequency
defs.docs: Frequency of the concentric objects.

attributes.value: / Frequency of the concentric objects.

defs.name: BasicMulti
defs.docs: Noise function that outputs heterogenous Multifractal noise.

attributes.value: / Noise function that outputs heterogenous Multifractal noise.
/ This is a multifractal method, meaning that it has a fractal dimension
/ that varies with location.
/ The result of this multifractal method is that in areas near zero, higher
/ frequencies will be heavily damped, resulting in the terrain remaining
/ smooth. As the value moves further away from zero, higher frequencies will
/ not be as damped and thus will grow more jagged as iteration progresses.

defs.name: octaves
defs.docs: Total number of frequency octaves to generate the noise with.

attributes.value: / Total number of frequency octaves to generate the noise with.
/ The number of octaves control the _amount of detail_ in the noise
/ function. Adding more octaves increases the detail, with the drawback
/ of increasing the calculation time.

defs.name: frequency
defs.docs: The number of cycles per unit length that the noise function outputs.

attributes.value: / The number of cycles per unit length that the noise function outputs.

defs.name: lacunarity
defs.docs:
A multiplier that determines how quickly the frequency increases for
 each successive octave in the noise function.

attributes.value: / A multiplier that determines how quickly the frequency increases for
/ each successive octave in the noise function.
/ The frequency of each successive octave is equal to the product of the
/ previous octave's frequency and the lacunarity value.
/ A lacunarity of 2.0 results in the frequency doubling every octave. For
/ almost all cases, 2.0 is a good value to use.

defs.name: persistence
defs.docs:
A multiplier that determines how quickly the amplitudes diminish for
 each successive octave in the noise function.

attributes.value: / A multiplier that determines how quickly the amplitudes diminish for
/ each successive octave in the noise function.
/ The amplitude of each successive octave is equal to the product of the
/ previous octave's amplitude and the persistence value. Increasing the
/ persistence produces "rougher" noise.

defs.name: Billow
defs.docs: Noise function that outputs "billowy" noise.

attributes.value: / Noise function that outputs "billowy" noise.
/ This noise function produces "billowy" noise suitable for clouds and rocks.
/ This noise function is nearly identical to fBm noise, except this noise
/ function modifies each octave with an absolute-value function. See the
/ documentation for fBm for more information.

defs.name: Fbm
defs.docs: Noise function that outputs fBm (fractal Brownian motion) noise.

attributes.value: / Noise function that outputs fBm (fractal Brownian motion) noise.
/ fBm is a _monofractal_ method. In essence, fBm has a _constant_ fractal
/ dimension. It is as close to statistically _homogeneous_ and _isotropic_
/ as possible. Homogeneous means "the same everywhere" and isotropic means
/ "the same in all directions" (note that the two do not mean the same
/ thing).
/ The main difference between fractal Brownian motion and regular Brownian
/ motion is that while the increments in Brownian motion are independent,
/ the increments in fractal Brownian motion depend on the previous increment.
/ fBm is the result of several noise functions of ever-increasing frequency
/ and ever-decreasing amplitude.
/ fBm is commonly referred to as Perlin noise.

defs.name: RidgedMulti
defs.value: RidgedMulti { octaves, frequency, lacunarity, persistence, attenuation }
defs.docs: Noise function that outputs ridged-multifractal noise.

attributes.value: / Noise function that outputs ridged-multifractal noise.
/ This noise function, heavily based on the fBm-noise function, generates
/ ridged-multifractal noise. Ridged-multifractal noise is generated in much
/ the same way as fBm noise, except the output of each octave is modified by
/ an absolute-value function. Modifying the octave values in this way
/ produces ridge-like formations.
/ The values output from this function will usually range from -1.0 to 1.0 with
/ default values for the parameters, but there are no guarantees that all
/ output values will exist within this range. If the parameters are modified
/ from their defaults, then the output will need to be scaled to remain in
/ the [-1,1] range.
/ Ridged-multifractal noise is often used to generate craggy mountainous
/ terrain or marble-like textures.

defs.name: octaves
defs.docs: Total number of frequency octaves to generate the noise with.

attributes.value: / Total number of frequency octaves to generate the noise with.
/ The number of octaves control the _amount of detail_ in the noise
/ function. Adding more octaves increases the detail, with the drawback
/ of increasing the calculation time.

attributes.value: / A multiplier that determines how quickly the amplitudes diminish for

/ The amplitude of each successive octave is equal to the product of the
/ previous octave's amplitude and the persistence value. Increasing the
/ persistence produces "rougher" noise.

defs.name: attenuation
defs.docs:
The attenuation to apply to the weight on each octave. This reduces
 the strength of each successive octave, making their respective
 ridges smaller. The default attenuation is 2.0, making each octave
 half the height of the previous.

attributes.value: / The attenuation to apply to the weight on each octave. This reduces
/ the strength of each successive octave, making their respective
/ ridges smaller. The default attenuation is 2.0, making each octave
/ half the height of the previous.

defs.name: displacement
defs.docs: Scale of the random displacement to apply to each cell.

attributes.value: / Scale of the random displacement to apply to each cell.
/ The noise function assigns each Worley cell a random constant value from
/ a value noise function. The `displacement` _value_ controls the range
/ random values to assign to each cell. The range of random values is +/-
/ the displacement value.

defs.name: Euclidean
defs.docs:
The standard linear distance. Expensive to compute because it requires
 square root calculations.

attributes.value: / The standard linear distance. Expensive to compute because it requires
/ square root calculations.

defs.name: EuclideanSquared
defs.docs:
Same as Euclidean, but without the square root calculations. Distance
 results will be smaller, however, but hash patterns will be the same.

attributes.value: / Same as Euclidean, but without the square root calculations. Distance
/ results will be smaller, however, but hash patterns will be the same.

defs.name: Manhattan
defs.docs:
Measured by only moving in straight lines along the axes. Diagonal
 movement is not allowed, which leads to increased distances.

attributes.value: / Measured by only moving in straight lines along the axes. Diagonal
/ movement is not allowed, which leads to increased distances.

defs.name: Chebyshev
defs.docs:
Measured by taking the largest distance along any axis as the total
 distance. Since this eliminates all but one dimension, it results in
 significantly shorter distances and produces regions where the
 distances are uniform.

attributes.value: / Measured by taking the largest distance along any axis as the total
/ distance. Since this eliminates all but one dimension, it results in
/ significantly shorter distances and produces regions where the
/ distances are uniform.

defs.name: Quadratic
defs.docs:
Experimental function where all values are multiplied together and then
 added up like a quadratic equation.

attributes.value: / Experimental function where all values are multiplied together and then
/ added up like a quadratic equation.

defs.name: RangeFunction
defs.value:
pub enum RangeFunction {
    Euclidean,
    EuclideanSquared,
    Manhattan,
    Chebyshev,
    Quadratic,
}

defs.name: Curve
defs.docs:
Noise function that maps the output value from the source function onto an
 arbitrary function curve.

attributes.value: / Noise function that maps the output value from the source function onto an
/ arbitrary function curve.
/ This noise function maps the output value from the source function onto an
/ application-defined curve. The curve is defined by a number of _control
/ points_; each control point has an _input value_ that maps to an _output
/ value_.
/ To add control points to the curve, use the `add_control_point` method.
/ Since the curve is a cubic spline, an application must have a minimum of
/ four control points to the curve. If there is less than four control
/ points, the get() method panics. Each control point can have any input
/ and output value, although no two control points can have the same input.

defs.name: Exponent
defs.docs:
Noise function that maps the output value from the source function onto an
 exponential curve.

attributes.value: / Noise function that maps the output value from the source function onto an
/ exponential curve.
/ Because most noise functions will output values that range from -1.0 to 1.0,
/ this noise function first normalizes the output value (the range becomes 0.0
/ to 1.0), maps that value onto an exponential curve, then rescales that
/ value back to the original range.

defs.name: Terrace
defs.docs:
Noise function that maps the output value from the source function onto a
 terrace-forming curve.

attributes.value: / Noise function that maps the output value from the source function onto a
/ terrace-forming curve.
/ This noise function maps the output value from the source function onto a
/ terrace-forming curve. The start of the curve has a slode of zero; it's
/ slope then smoothly increases. This curve also contains _control points_
/ which resets the slope to zero at that point, producing a "terracing"
/ effect.
/ To add control points to the curve, use the `add_control_point` method.
/ An application must add a minimum of two control points to the curve. If
/ there are less than two control points, the get() method panics. The
/ control points can have any value, although no two control points can
/ have the same value. There is no limit to the number of control points
/ that can be added to the curve.
/ The noise function clamps the output value from the source function if that
/ value is less than the value of the lowest control point or greater than
/ the value of the highest control point.
/ This noise function is often used to generate terrain features such as the
/ stereotypical desert canyon.

defs.name: source
defs.docs: Outputs a value.

attributes.value: / Outputs a value.

defs.name: invert_terraces
defs.docs:
Determines if the terrace-forming curve between all control points is
 inverted.

attributes.value: / Determines if the terrace-forming curve between all control points is
/ inverted.

defs.name: new
defs.value: pub fn new(&'a dyn NoiseFn<T>) -> Self

defs.name: add_control_point
defs.docs: Adds a control point to the terrace-forming curve.

attributes.value: / Adds a control point to the terrace-forming curve.
/ Two or more control points define the terrace-forming curve. The start
/ of this curve has a slope of zero; its slope then smoothly increases.
/ At the control points, its slope resets to zero.
/ It does not matter which order these points are added in.

defs.name: invert_terraces
defs.docs:
Enables or disables the inversion of the terrain-forming curve between
 the control points.

attributes.value: / Enables or disables the inversion of the terrain-forming curve between
/ the control points.

defs.name: Blend
defs.docs:
Noise function that outputs a weighted blend of the output values from two
 source functions given the output value supplied by a control function.

attributes.value: / Noise function that outputs a weighted blend of the output values from two
/ source functions given the output value supplied by a control function.
/ This noise function uses linear interpolation to perform the blending
/ operation.

defs.name: source1
defs.docs: Outputs one of the values to blend.

attributes.value: / Outputs one of the values to blend.

defs.name: source2
defs.docs: Outputs one of the values to blend.

attributes.value: / Outputs one of the values to blend.

defs.name: control
defs.docs:
Determines the weight of the blending operation. Negative values weight
 the blend towards the output value from the `source1` function. Positive
 values weight the blend towards the output value from the `source2`
 function.

attributes.value: / Determines the weight of the blending operation. Negative values weight
/ the blend towards the output value from the `source1` function. Positive
/ values weight the blend towards the output value from the `source2`
/ function.

defs.name: source1
defs.docs: Outputs a value.

attributes.value: / Outputs a value.

defs.name: source2
defs.docs: Outputs a value.

attributes.value: / Outputs a value.

defs.name: control
defs.docs:
Determines the value to select. If the output value from
 the control function is within a range of values know as the _selection
 range_, this noise function outputs the value from `source2`.
 Otherwise, this noise function outputs the value from `source1`.

attributes.value: / Determines the value to select. If the output value from
/ the control function is within a range of values know as the _selection
/ range_, this noise function outputs the value from `source2`.
/ Otherwise, this noise function outputs the value from `source1`.

defs.name: bounds
defs.docs: Bounds of the selection range. Default is 0.0 to 1.0.

attributes.value: / Bounds of the selection range. Default is 0.0 to 1.0.

defs.name: falloff
defs.docs: Edge falloff value. Default is 0.0.

attributes.value: / Edge falloff value. Default is 0.0.

defs.name: Displace
defs.value: Displace { source, x_displace, y_displace, z_displace, u_displace }
defs.docs:
Noise function that uses multiple source functions to displace each coordinate
 of the input value before returning the output value from the `source` function.

attributes.value: / Noise function that uses multiple source functions to displace each coordinate
/ of the input value before returning the output value from the `source` function.

defs.docs: Source function that outputs a value

attributes.value: / Source function that outputs a value

defs.name: x_displace
defs.docs:
Displacement function that displaces the _x_ coordinate of the input
 value.

attributes.value: / Displacement function that displaces the _x_ coordinate of the input
/ value.

defs.name: y_displace
defs.docs:
Displacement function that displaces the _y_ coordinate of the input
 value.

attributes.value: / Displacement function that displaces the _y_ coordinate of the input
/ value.

defs.name: z_displace
defs.docs:
Displacement function that displaces the _z_ coordinate of the input
 value. Only needed for 3d or higher noise.

attributes.value: / Displacement function that displaces the _z_ coordinate of the input
/ value. Only needed for 3d or higher noise.

defs.name: u_displace
defs.docs:
Displacement function that displaces the _u_ coordinate of the input
 value. Only needed for 4d or higher noise.

attributes.value: / Displacement function that displaces the _u_ coordinate of the input
/ value. Only needed for 4d or higher noise.

defs.value: pub fn new(Source, XDisplace, YDisplace, ZDisplace, UDisplace) -> Self

defs.name: RotatePoint
defs.value: RotatePoint { source, x_angle, y_angle, z_angle, u_angle }
defs.docs:
Noise function that rotates the input value around the origin before
 returning the output value from the source function.

attributes.value: / Noise function that rotates the input value around the origin before
/ returning the output value from the source function.
/ The get() method rotates the coordinates of the input value around the
/ origin before returning the output value from the source function.
/ The coordinate system of the input value is assumed to be "right-handed"
/ (_x_ increases to the right, _y_ increases upward, and _z_ increases inward).

defs.name: source
defs.docs: Source function that outputs a value

attributes.value: / Source function that outputs a value

defs.name: x_angle
defs.docs:
_x_ rotation angle applied to the input value, in degrees. The
 default angle is set to 0.0 degrees.

attributes.value: / _x_ rotation angle applied to the input value, in degrees. The
/ default angle is set to 0.0 degrees.

defs.docs:

defs.name: Turbulence
defs.docs:
Noise function that randomly displaces the input value before returning the
 output value from the source function.

attributes.value: / Noise function that randomly displaces the input value before returning the
/ output value from the source function.
/ _ is the pseudo-random displacement of the input value. The
/ get() method randomly displaces the coordinates of the input value before
/ retrieving the output value from the source function. To control the
/ turbulence, an application can modify its frequency, its power, and its
/ roughness.

defs.name: source
defs.docs: Source function that outputs a value.

attributes.value: / Source function that outputs a value.

defs.name: frequency
defs.docs: Frequency value for the Turbulence function.

attributes.value: / Frequency value for the Turbulence function.

defs.name: power
defs.docs:
Controls the strength of the turbulence by affecting how much each
 point is moved.

attributes.value: / Controls the strength of the turbulence by affecting how much each
/ point is moved.

defs.name: roughness
defs.docs: Affects the roughness of the turbulence. Higher values are rougher.

attributes.value: / Affects the roughness of the turbulence. Higher values are rougher.

defs.name: NoiseFn
defs.docs: Base trait for noise functions.

attributes.value: / Base trait for noise functions.
/ A noise function is a object that calculates and outputs a value given a
/ n-Dimensional input value, where n is (2,3,4).
/ Each type of noise function uses a specific method to calculate an output
/ value. Some of these methods include:
/ * Calculating a value using a coherent-noise function or some other
/     mathematical function.
/ * Mathematically changing the output value from another noise function
/     in various ways.
/ * Combining the output values from two noise functions in various ways.

defs.docs: Trait for functions that require a seed before generating their values

attributes.value: / Trait for functions that require a seed before generating their values

attributes.value: / Set the seed for the function implementing the `Seedable` trait

defs.docs: Getter to retrieve the seed from the function

attributes.value: / Getter to retrieve the seed from the function
